title: Laning vs Cait Leona, disgusting CC and tank with crazy damage.
body:
I will start this off by saying I am not a bot laner. But everyone gets filled there from time to time. 

Now this isnt a lane that I see all the time but Cait is pretty common, and with CoC, hard CC sups seem to be more FOTM atm. 
They just have such a huge poke and engage range and the ability to pile on CC while Leo seems to just ignore my adc and take barely any damage even though she dove into a creep wave and is tanking minions too while Caits range means she just sits far back and autos and if you dare try to engage on Cait you end up sitting on a cupcake and getting destroyed. {{item:3070}} {{item:3070}} 

I would normally play casters as a sup, Sona Lux Brand Morg or maybe Malphite or Ali if we need the hard engage and tank, and my tank sup page is 28 arm and 12 mr and 2.7 mr @18, for casters its usually my safe mid page with res yellows and blues or my 26 ap 15 arm page.

ATM I feel like if im filled and see Cait and Leo on enemy team I should just dodge and hope for a better matchup next game.

Thoughts on the lane matchup? Fave counters? Thoughts on dodging when you see a certain enemy comp vs your comp?

replies.body:
Morgana is about as hard a counter to Leona as you can get, so Morg would be a good pick. 
Sivir also counters Leona, and I believe she isn't too shabby against Caitlin either.

So you could be looking at a Sivir/Morgana lane.

Or maybe a Varus/Morgana lane, as Varus can match Cait's poke, and his ult combined with Morgana's Q/R would spell certain death for any opponent unlucky enough to be caught in it.

Im not a bot laner either, Kalista/Quinn are the only two ADC's I can play, and both of them are pretty horrible against Cait/Leo, so don't trust my advice too much xD

But to answer your dodge question:
Never dodge. Imagine if the Wallabies chickened out before every match with the All Blacks, that doesn't make good sport for anyone.
If you get dealt a bad hand, you shouldn't just give up. _(if you give up when things look tough, how will you ever learn?)_

Never dodging is, imo, a terrible idea. 3LP compared to somewhere around 15-20, but it does not affect your MMR so you should continue to gain LP at the same rate. 15LP is 5x3. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qy3Mibl4fXI  He discusses dodging around 1 min but the whole vid is worth watching. 
Anyone who plays poker or just understands odds and mitigation should understand that while you shouldnt do it too much, dodging is a GOOD thing to do, and when you get dealt a bad hand you fold. 
Pros and streamers dont do it for different reasons, and there are some incredibly high ranked players who climb there dodging every time they dont get their role/champ. 

> [{quoted}](name=JesusForgotHisGA,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=Gb5mImfm,comment-id=0004,timestamp=2017-01-08T04:18:59.626+0000)
>
> Morgana for sure. If she E's your adc simply shield them in return, Q Cait (or simply walk into her), ult and enjoy the free kills.

I think you forgot the part where Cait can shoot past minions but Morg Q cant, same with Leo E and R, and the fact that Cait can usually kill Morg before her ult finishes, depending items and level.

Sure dodging is a way to avoid LP loss, but its hardly an honourable thing to do.

No one likes anyone who quits because they're too afraid of losing. 
Plus you are more likely to win if you learn how to play into a disadvantageous game.

and its not Morgs's Q that counters Leo, its her Black Shield, it renders all of Leona's CC useless, which turns the lane into a 2v1 situation.

But any decent Leo will E to one person and then Q the person who isnt shielded who Cait also drops a trap under and nets if no minions in the way and Leo ults resulting in about 5 seconds of not being able to do very much at all. 
And that is still reliant on your adc not being stupid and walking on top of you allowing Leo a double E or at least a fat target that is much harder to shield against. 

I did say I play Morg, I understand the matchup, I just feel like this is the most abusive and obnoxious bot lane which punishes you for mistakes more than it is possible to punish them for theirs.

Also, honourable? WTF bro, I play this for fun and to gain ELO, no offense but you can shove your honour you know where. More than half of this game is cheesing and abusing enemies. 
Would you not gank a lane because 3v2 is not honourable? Would you allow someone to catch up with you because its not honourable to pick on someone 3 levels down who you can just stomp all over? Would you let the enemy take towers because you already took a couple of theirs so the only honourable thing to do would be to let them take some back?

Morg will likely shield the ADC meaning Leona wastes her stun on Morgana, which means Cait has 2 choices

1. Attack Sivir/Varus, and ignore the stun on Morg (making the fight just a 1v1 between the ADC's, and Cait will likely lose a 1v1 to Sivir or Varus)
2. Attack Morgana, dying to Sivir/Varus in the process.

Either way you gain more than you lose.

And yea its a game, have some good sportsmanship man. Its not just about you having fun, its about everyone, and no one has fun when people aren't sportsmanlike.

> [{quoted}](name=Lord Sesshomaru,realm=OCE,application-id=FjGAIbRv,discussion-id=Gb5mImfm,comment-id=00030001000000000000,timestamp=2017-01-08T12:05:13.791+0000)
>

Please explain how a dodge is unsportsmanlike and how it effects anyone else beyond a small delay in getting into their game? 
I would much rather wait for a game with people who are going into it with a positive view and who probably wont tilt easily from X champion etc. 
You can dodge 5 or more times and lose the same LP as a single loss. If you think that dodging is bad then im not sure you know how to math / dont understand mmr/elo. 

Your account in level 9 indicating to me that you dont play this game or that you dont want to show your real account, probably so no one can look at your rank and match history. Hiding your real acc doesnt seem very sportsmanlike does it? 

"Never dodge. Imagine if the Wallabies chickened out before every match with the All Blacks, that doesn't make good sport for anyone."

Dude are you actually comparing low elo ranked league gameplay to professional athletes representing their country? LOL.
Pay me to play and idgaf who you match me with. You are using the very pinnacle of a sport to compare? Stop trolling bro, trolling isnt very sportsmanlike. 

While I want everyone to enjoy themselves, when I queue up for ranked my number 1 priority is to win. It is to climb elo. To do that I have to learn stuff and I totally understand odds and that you wont win every game and sometimes you get bad matchups. But minimising the risk vs reward is not unsporting, its smart.

A dodge is unsportsmanlike because you're essentially saying "I don't want to play with you, just incase you're better than me." which is pretty damn unsportsmanlike.

The banning phase exists so that you can ban some of the champs you don't want to play against. If Riot expected you to dodge every time you got a bad matchup then they wouldn't have bothered to make a banning phase.

Let me put it bluntly: You are not expected to dodge a game because you get a bad matchup. Thats just fact! Dodging bad matchups is NOT the intended gameplay for the game. Therefore, if you do dodge, you aren't actually playing as you're expected to, and so are actually being unsportsmanlike.

And yes I'm comparing low elo to professional athletes, because if you were to show someone the 'true' game of rugby, what would you show them? Would you show them the All Blacks, or would you show them a bunch of kids kicking a ball round in the back garden? 
The whole point of an analogy is to compare contrasting circumstances in a way that makes the contrast clear, and you do that by showing the extreme ends of the spectrum.

Anyway only bad players dodge games, (you don't see Faker dodging any do you? No, because he is good enough to play into whatever lane he gets.) Dodging basically is saying "Im not good enough to play against this lane."

In any case, you asked for our thoughts on dodging, I gave my thoughts, I can hardly be blamed if you don't like it.

Actually dodging is part of a strategy that high elo players use to get where they are, its part of the gameplay knowledge side of league. 

Like OP stated, it is much better to lose 3 LP and have to wait 5mins than to suffer for 20+mins and lost 15+ LP. 

There are multiple reasons a player would and should dodge, for example:

* being matched with a player they know was lagging last game
* Being matched with someone with a really low win rate or a massive losing streak (a reason checking your allies history with the op.gg group function is a good idea)
* having a mix-match of champions that don't really amount to a clear way of winning the game (do we split push, do we group, do we siege) vs a team that looks like they did a proper draft
* having your first team fight in champ select


You can't really compare ranked games to pro-athletes in the way that pro athletes complete a set amount of games, while gamers can play anywhere from a "casual" to a "die at the computer" number of games. 

For those on the more casual end of the spectrum, it is wise to dodge to make the games they do have time to play count. 
Likewise, for players that are glued to their gaming setups 24/7, dodging a game that you know is going to tilt you off the face of the earth is worth it, because then you don't have to try and reset your mindset before the next game. 

Im not saying to dodge every unfavourable game (the penalties do stack up really fast), because like you said learning to play at a disadvantage is a skill that many players lack due to the giving up/ ff @20 attitude, but dodging now and again isn't a bad thing.

You make many good points, and I can see how it can be beneficial, but as strategic as it may be, I don't think dodging is a exemplary way to play the game.

You are punished _(queue timers)_ for dodging, and I find it hard to believe that you can be punished for playing a game _(wether its league, or CoD, or Rugby)_ the way it is expected to be played, therefore I can't believe dodging games is how the game is intended to be played.

_(Comparing this again to high level sport sorry :S)_ It feels like in a game of soccer, "accidentally" smashing the best player on the other team in the shin _(making him unable to play)_ and then accepting the yellow card penalty for a few minutes, before going back to the field and winning because they are down their bast player.
That is a genuine strategy, and people do it, but its hardly sportsmanlike.

Im not arguing that people don't dodge and use it to get higher elo, and I'm not arguing that it doesn't work.
Im just saying I personally don't believe its a very sportsmanlike thing to do, to give up before the game has even started.

If I am to get a higher rank, I would rather get there through hard work and skill, rather than taking advantage of the system, and shunning other players just because they've had an unlucky streak. 

I suppose thats just me though. 

If one of my allies has a massive losing streak, I would rather help them win, than shove them off like a disease. 
_(Imagine how they must feel, when they get dodgers every game, just because they've had an unlucky streak.)_

Im sorry but you cant convince me that thats a sportsmanlike thing to do.
Ive had massive unlucky streaks, but how are you supposed to recover from them, when no one will play with you?

I can agree that dodging has benefits and may indeed help you get high elo, but OP is talking about dodging just because your main champ gets banned.
_______

I personally believe that most people don't have good stickability and give up way too easily.

But in any case, thank you for good response, I see I was indeed wrong about some things.

"(you don't see Faker dodging any do you? No, because he is good enough to play into whatever lane he gets"

He is a professional, one of the top 10 players out of millions, who might, in competition, end up with a bad matchup for team comp or pick order reasons and is expected to be able to play at the **absolute highest level of play**. Do you think a low elo player would learn more by being roflstomped by Faker or by watching Fakers VODs and analyzing his decisions and build without any pressure? I have no delusions of grandeur. I do not think I am Faker, able to take on any matchup and win because my skill, game knowledge, reactions and equipment are all top notch, like 0.00000001% kind of elite. 

"And yes I'm comparing low elo to professional athletes, because if you were to show someone the 'true' game of rugby, what would you show them?"
Would you expect them to play like that if they were an amateur and tell them to expect everyone else on their amateur team plays at the same level? Would you tell them to utilise tactics that the very highest level players are capable of or would you tell them to get good at the basics? The top rugby kickers can nail a kick from halfway pretty regularly. Would you tell them if they cant do that it isnt really rugby?
There is a reason why there is a problem with balancing competitive play vs normal play. The very highest skill players are capable of maximising every single part of their kit and minimising their mistakes. There is a reason why competitive picks and bans do not always align with normal play bans. Remember Kalista in comp play? So OP they nerfed her to the point she is trash for normal play. Same for Azir. 

"The banning phase exists so that you can ban some of the champs you don't want to play against. If Riot expected you to dodge every time you got a bad matchup then they wouldn't have bothered to make a banning phase."

Currently only 3 people per team get to choose bans. If you are one of the other 2 people on your team that do not get to choose bans then effectively the ban phase is out of your control and you do not get to ban any of the champions you dont want to play against, and I noticed you used champs, as in plural. Well kiddo, you only get one ban **if ** you are one of those 3 people so your argument falls flat there. 

Riot even had/have a program IRL called Queue Dodge for employees to bail. Indicating to me that they see real reasons for dodging both in game and IRL. To repeat my earlier analogy, a good poker player knows when to fold. Sportsmanship relates to behavior towards team mates and opposition. Playing a bad hand purely because thats what you were dealt so you have to play it to the bitter end is a bad way to play poker, LOL and life in general. In a relationship with an abusive partner? Oh well that is just the hand you were dealt so you better just suck it up and play it out to the bitter end. In a job you hate? Oh well, you started it so you had better stick with it. 

I notice you fail to address the account issue. Rather unsporting imo. So if this is your main then you are a level 9 player trying to explain things you havent experienced, if this isnt your main you are hiding it for some shady reason. Anyone with any real sportsmanship does not hide behind a false name/account. In light of such, anything you say would at best be taken with a grain of salt, if not regarded very dubiously indeed.

You are the one who tried to give the reason of sportsmanship as why to not dodge but sportsmanship is very subjective and what one person might find entirely within the rules another might find to be unsporting. But guess what mate. The rules decide who wins the game. Not subjective opinions on fair play. To play the game to the maximum extent allowed by the rules is the smart way to play and your argument is predicated on the fact that you should not try to win if its somehow not fair, to which my response is, if you get a lead on someone and continue to beat them because they cannot 1v1 you that could be seen as  unsporting. Would you give up your lead and allow them to get a few kills and farm freely for a while to catch up? If not then your "unsportsmanlike" argument is worthless. 
Unsporting behavior relates to general BM, taunting, abusive language and sore loser/winner type of behavior. 
A boxer does not take on fights he knows are a bad matchup unless he is getting paid well enough for the trouble. Once you bring in professionals, as in someone who does something as a way to earn money, then your point about rugby becomes relevant. In casual and amateur games and sports it is preposterous. Quite often casual competitions see forfeits when the matchup is known to be uneven. 

My point was about how your perception of sportsmanship is subjective to your reality and does not necessarily coincide with others which makes arguing it is not sporting to be irrelevant.

Greetings Mortis Ex,

To answer your question on how to vs Caitlyn and Leona as a lane matchup let me first break up the two champions and touch on each one individually before I note on them as a combo. 
---

# Caitlyn

Starting with Caitlyn the first thing we need to understand is her insane amount of Range as an ADC. Caitlyn as one of the highest auto attack ranges in the game at 650. With this in mind unless you are playing someone like Annie (who has a high auto attack range), you usually don't want to take auto attack trades with her.

Use your abilities to your advantage to poke her down if you are able too along with going for quick trades making sure that you aren't in a position to get hit by her E > Q combo which can do a lot of damage. So for the most part I would suggest fighting within your minion wave.

Be careful with the trades that you take and if you can try not to take auto attacks for free. Sometimes its ok to give up a minion or two if it means not taking 100 health in damage from auto attacks. When you think about it means you will be in the lane longer to get other cs that you would have missed, having being forced to go back. (This is mainly a TIP for ADCs but can still apply to supports for when your ADC is taking cs and you can communicative this too them with something such as a ping.)

---

The next thing that I would like to note is is Caitlyn's passive. Every 6 auto attacks Caitlyn will get extra damage on her next auto attack, it is your job to look out for the visual queue for this (her gun glowing) and try not to get hit by it. Along with this when Caitlyn is in a brush, every auto attack that she hits counts as two auto attacks towards getting those 6 stacks, so if you can try to avoid fighting in bushes.

---

Now Caitlyn's traps can be very painful to deal with, the alter the terrain of the bot lane in a sense limiting the locations that you can walk to. The best option that you have when dealing with Caitlyn traps is trying to ignore them, or force them to place them in areas that isn't beneficial to them in the lane by being positioned in those areas. As a support sometimes it can be ok to tank the damage from Caitlyn's passive that you are going to take when clearing out the traps, but be careful when you do this as you will be snared and people will be able to punish you for it.

---

# Leona

Onto Leona, the first thing that you need to be careful of is her level two power spike. This can be extremely deadly and is something that you really need to look out for. Usually Leona's will start with their Q or E and then pick up the other the second they hit level 2, letting them dash onto you and stun you, setting up their ADC to do free damage to you. 

* For a point of reference it takes the first wave of minions, plus the 3 melee minions in XP for a duo lane to hit level 2. This is something that you should be watching for and aware of.

---

The next thing is warding the in lane bush. Leona players love sitting in the bush until their E is up waiting for a time to strike, if you ward the bush this makes the Leona have a lot harder of a time doing this. I would recommend getting this ward down while they are still level 1 and it is hard for them to punish you for doing so. 

---

After that we have the main thing to take advantage of at level one which is that Leona isn't a ranged champion. This is something that you want to punish hard, try to get auto attacks on her when she can't stop you by kiting her and punishing her for trying to stack her targons. However do be careful if she is trying to bait you into a level 2 power spike fight, always try to keep track of how close they are to leveling up.

---

After that we have positioning in the lane, usually you don't want to stick close your ADC and Mirror Leona's movements around the lane. If you are a squishy support such as Sona this is even more important. If she moves down towards the bush, you might want to consider moving up a bit towards the river, putting as much range between you and the Leona that wants to engage on you as possible. The other reason that you don't want to stick close to your ADC is in the case of Leona ulting, you don't want to both be stunned.

---

# Leona and Caitlyn as a duo lane.

As for Caitlyn and Leona as a duo lane, the first thing to look out for from them is their CC combos. Often what will happen in this lane is that a Leona will E onto you and stun you, and then Caitlyn will place a trap under you while you are stunned giving you no chance to react. Getting CC chained is something that you want to try and avoid at all costs.

Try to poke when you can taking away their HP slowly as you can. Take slightly longer trades if they do engage on you as once Leona's combo is gone, she won't have it up for a decent amount of time. So get in what poke that you can, and then disengage before her combo is back up again.

---

The other thing to look out for which is a fancy trick that this lane can do is that when Caitlyn wants to ult a low target, she can start channeling her ult while Leona goes on the other target that will try to block it, CC locking them before they have a chance to get in front of the bullet. So this is something to be aware of that they can do and be careful of.

---

# Final notes

A lot of this lane is learning what Leona and Caitlyn's strengths and weaknesses are and then learning to take advantage of them. Try to disengage when they engage on you and peel for your ADC as much as you can. Always keep in mind though, that if their Leona engages on you as a support, your ADC is untouched and can do free damage, just something to keep in mind.

I hope that this helps, if there is any questions I can answer or anything I can clarify on let me know! Good luck in your games!
